title: Recovering RBS clears path to dividends at last
text:

Sun, Oct 25, 2015, 04:45 GMT - UK Markets closed Recovering RBS clears path to dividends at last By Tim Wallace | Telegraph – 8 hours ago 8.40 +0.19 
Strong finances could lead to a payout to shareholders next year, the first since 2008 and ahead of the bank’s 2017 schedule 
Royal Bank of Scotland (LSE: RBS.L - news ) has built its capital buffers back up to a level that could allow the bank to pay its first dividend since it was bailed out at the height of the financial crisis. 
Bosses at the bank have earmarked 2017 for the resumption of dividends or share buybacks , but analysts believe that a small payout could be paid to investors next year if revenue and lending continues to grow, boosting its balance sheet. 
The resumption of shareholder payments would be the latest step in returning to a normal, profitable position. 
RBS last paid a dividend in 2008, shortly before it collapsed and had to be rescued by the Government. 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) is expected to report further progress in its third quarter results this week. 
Analysts at Bernstein Research expect RBS to announce that its core capital buffers have grown to 12.6pc — rising to 15.6pc when the final chunk of American bank Citizens (NYSE: CIA - news ) is sold. 
Such figures would be well above the level required by regulators, meaning the bank has resources available to return to shareholders. 
Sustained economic growth is helping to drive revenues at the bank as lending increases and the level of bad loans falls. 
Analysts at Bernstein Research expect RBS will show its core capital buffers have grown to 12.6pc, and when the final chunk of US bank Citizens is sold, 15.6pc well above the level required by regulators, meaning the bank has resources available to return to shareholders. 
“We are struggling to see how the bank will be prevented from paying a token dividend by the Bank of England,” said Bernstein’s Chirantan Barua, expecting a payout to come once RBS has sold off US bank Citizens . 
RBS floated Citizens in September 2014 and has reduced its stake to just 20.9pc of the bank. 
Before any dividend can be paid, the bank has to buy back the dividend access share from the Government at a cost of just over £1bn. 
The resumption of dividend payments would be the latest step in returning the bank to a normal, profitable position. 
In July the Government sold a £2.1bn stake in RBS , kicking off the process of privatising the lender and cutting the taxpayers’ share of the bank from 78.3pc to 73.2pc. 
Earlier this month the Government adjusted the type of shares it holds, moving some of its holdings from B shares with no voting rights, into ordinary shares, which carry voting rights. 
The complex setup originated because the government did not want RBS to have to give up its stock market listing following the bail out something which happens when one shareholder owns more than 75pc of the voting rights. 
As a result, the taxpayer's stake included some B Shares which gave ownership but not voting rights, getting around the rules. This system is now being simplified, preparing the bank further for privatisation. 
There are still some negative factors dragging down RBS’s financial results. 
Ian Gordon, an Investec (LSE: INVP.L - news ) analyst, expects RBS to pay a further £600m in compensation for PPI and other misconduct, as well as £800m in restructuring costs in its third quarter results. 
The bank is also awaiting a legal settlement for pre-crisis toxic loans sold in the US. This is expected to be in the region of $5bn (£3.3bn) but could come in at as much as $10bn . The bank will be the last of 18 banks to end the dispute with the Federal Housing Finance Agency. If RBS does not agree a settlement, the case is expected to come to court next year. 
However, Bernstein maintains that a small dividend is likely in spite of a “worst-case litigation outcome”. 
Any settlement should also help the bank's share price, as it removes a cloud hanging over the stock.
